user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CreateSocketName:
```c
void OS_CreateSocketName(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *parent_name)
{
    size_t                       len;
    uint16                       port;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *sock;

    sock = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, *token);

    if (OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name), Addr) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        sock->stream_name[0] = 0;
    }
    if (OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(&port, Addr) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, ":%u", (unsigned int)port);
    }

    if (parent_name)
    {
        /* Append the name from the parent socket. */
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, "-%s", parent_name);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CreateSocketName:
int32 OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(char *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    const void *                  addrbuffer;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in.sin_addr;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_addr;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    if (inet_ntop(Accessor->sa.sa_family, addrbuffer, buffer, buflen) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(uint16 *PortNum, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    in_port_t                     sa_port;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in.sin_port;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_port;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    *PortNum = ntohs(sa_port);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in the provided target or related code uses the Standard Library function memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. A search of the shown code finds only the following string-related operations, none of which are memcmp-based comparisons and thus are not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14:
- OS_strnlen uses memchr to find the terminating NUL (not memcmp) and returns a length.
- snprintf is used to append formatted data (port and parent_name) into stream_name (not a memcmp comparison).
- OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl uses inet_ntop to write a textual address into a buffer (no memcmp).
- OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl extracts and returns a port number (no memcmp).
- The macros and table/index accessors do not perform string comparisons.

Because there are no uses of memcmp in the supplied code, there are no fragments that need to be investigated for Rule 21.14. If additional source files or omitted functions exist, please provide them so they can be inspected for any memcmp usage comparing null-terminated strings.
